Last night, the Board of Education held a special meeting to amend the 2020-2021 school year calendar. Two options were presented for review and possible adoption, one calendar with a student start date of Tuesday, September 1, and another calendar with a student start date of Tuesday, September 8. Both calendar options also kept Wednesday, May 26 as the last day of school. At the meeting, the Board approved the calendar which has a Tuesday, September 1 student start date. You can view the amended calendar here: https://bit.ly/3gROanL

The shifting of some PLC days to the beginning of the school year allows our staff members much needed time for collaboration to prepare for virtual learning and potential school closures. In addition, it allows time for modifications necessary for in-seat learning.

We appreciate your continued patience as we make adjustments to provide the best and safest educational environment for the upcoming school year.

One kit will go to each of our 4 buildings and be mounted alongside our AED units & EpiPen kits. During the Stop the Bleed course, they learned the three quick techniques to help save a life before someone bleeds out: (1) How to use your hands to apply pressure to a wound; (2) How to pack a wound to control bleeding; (3) How to correctly apply a tourniquet. Stop The Bleed ACS is an organization committed to better preparing the public to save lives if people nearby are severely bleeding.

One kit will go to each of our 4 buildings and be mounted alongside our AED units & EpiPen kits. Kits are now available in all four buildings through a grant from Boone Electric Cooperative and MU's Trauma/Surgical Specialties Department. Primary and Intermediate staff will be offered the training soon. MU Health Care

Mrs. Griffin's kindergarten class is focusing on writing! Part of the new literacy curriculum, Being A Writer, has students focusing on telling more in their stories. The process takes three days each week to complete. Before they write, the students think and talk about what they want to say. After they write, they revisit their drawings and writings and think about what they can add to them. Students write shared stories, choose topics for their own stories and share their forms of writing with peers. ‚úç

A very powerful part of this process is peer conferencing with each other. They each love showing what they have done in writing each day with other in the classroom.

Ms. Herndon's HMS art classes recently learned about "Dia de los Muertos" or "Day of the Dead," a Mexican holiday that is celebrated on November 1st and 2nd. It is a day to remember, celebrate, and honor the lives of family members that have passed away. They create altars in their homes with flowers, candles, pictures of the lost family members, along with their favorite food and drink items. One item on the altar is a candy Sugar Skull. It is to represent that life is sweet and not to be taken for granted.

As the students learned about a different culture and its' traditions, their objective was to create their own version
of a sugar skull. It is to represent the Mexican culture with bright colors, and symbols seen during Day of the Dead.
Some students got to paint and decorate a foam skull with puff paint and gems, while others use ink spray and metallic pens to create a vibrant sugar skull design on paper.

#HVLearn #WeAreHallsville

Detective Evans is a member of the Boone County Sheriff's Department and works for the Boone County Cyber Crimes Task Force. Along with investigating criminal activity related to the internet, they also provide educational presentations to students in grades 6-12 including parent presentations.

We are very thankful to Detective Evans and the Cyber Crimes Task Force for coming to Hallsville to educate our students.
